oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Discussion - Night Train to Nashville and The Beat tv show screening - 2004-05-22
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Panel discussion following the screening of two Nashville based TV shows titled Night Train to Nashville and The Beat!!! from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on May 22, 2004. In support of the exhibit "Night Train to Nashville: Music City Rhythm and Blues".
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ron Wynn; Michael Blackwell; Tracy Blackwell; Frank Howard; Johnny Jones; Billy Lockridge;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Discussion moderated by Ron Wynn. Includes questions from the audience. Subjects include: Night Train; The Beat!!!; Noble Blackwell -- Audio engineer Ray Caldwell and the TV station's first time with a black host -- Impact of Night Train -- bringing local talent to a national audience -- Noble Blackwell's influence -- memories of Night Train and the times -- Johnny Jones talks about his career -- Music director Bob Holmes -- Bill "Hoss" Allen -- Differences between Night Train and The Beat !!! -- Hoss Allen and recording with Pete Drake and Scotty Moore -- Music rehearsal or lack of -- Popularity of the shows -- Black and white audiences -- Exposure to white audiences and increase in personal appearances -- Playing with local white bands -- Origins of house bands and late night TV -- Working and performing together -- Rivalries - Freddie Waters -- Lack of technology and live performances -- Johnny Jones and learning how to play -- Nashville Rhythm and Blues music connections with Nashville country music -- Recording at Bradleys Barn -- Country musicians playing on R&B recording sessions - Buddy Killen -- Playing the chitlin' circuit and how Night Train's exposure changed that -- Nashville's diverse range of music -- Working for white record producers -- Jerry Crutchfield -- Jefferson Street clubs -- Johnny Jones losing himself in the music and the music scene -- Jimi Hendrix and Billy Cox -- Noble Blackwell's feeling about Night Train in his later years -- Introduction of Mrs. Noble Blackwell and comment from her in the audience.
